topic_seeds.description: Dealing with family dynamics and expectations
Questioning identity or sense of self
Providing minimal context about their situation

exchanges.user:
Work's been rough. I know I said I'd try to stop being so hard on myself about the deadline stuff, but honestly it's just getting worse. My manager pulled me aside yesterday and basically said the project's behind and it's my fault. Maybe it is. I don't know anymore.

Also my mom called and we got into it again about my sister's wedding next month. Apparently I'm supposed to give a speech but I haven't committed to going yet. She made it sound like I'm being selfish for not just saying yes automatically. Like my whole life should revolve around family events. Anyway I'm tired. How are you?
exchanges.assistant:
**Work and the deadline:**

Your manager said the project's behind and blamed you—that must've felt awful. The tricky part here is that you're already questioning yourself ("maybe it is"), which makes it hard to know if this is actually on you or if you're taking on blame that isn't fully yours. When you say "it's just getting worse," are you talking about the project timeline, or the way you're beating yourself up about it, or both?

One thing that stands out: you tried to stop being hard on yourself, but then your manager reinforced exactly the narrative you're trying to escape. That timing isn't nothing.

**Your mom and the wedding:**

It sounds like your mom's framing this as "you should just say yes" without room for whatever hesitation you're actually feeling. The word "selfish" is doing a lot of work there—it's shutting down the conversation before you even get to explain what's making this hard for you.

I'm curious what's behind the hesitation to commit. Is it the speech itself, or something else about being there? Because if you're genuinely not sure you can go, that's information worth listening to—not selfishness.

**"Anyway I'm tired. How are you?":**

I'm here to focus on you, but I hear the tiredness. That deflection at the end—"how are you?"—feels like a reflex, like you're used to making space for other people even when you're the one carrying a lot.

Which of these is pressing hardest right now—the work thing or the wedding thing? Or is it the combination of both happening at once?

exchanges.user:
work's still a mess. had another meeting this morning and turns out the deadline got moved up by a week. which is insane. so now my manager's mad at me for something that wasn't even possible to begin with, and i'm just supposed to what, work 80 hour weeks? i didn't even push back. just sat there nodding like an idiot.

the thing is, part of me knows this isn't totally on me. the requirements kept changing. but i also know i could've communicated better earlier instead of just... not saying anything until it was too late. so it's both, i guess.

anyway. didn't go to the wedding thing yet. mom's been texting. hasn't called again which is fine by me. i know i need to decide soon but every time i think about it i just feel this weight in my chest, like if i say no she'll never let it go. and if i say yes i'll resent everyone the whole time.

still tired.
exchanges.assistant:
**Work and the impossible deadline:**

They moved the deadline up a week, blamed you for being behind, and you sat there nodding instead of saying "this timeline was already tight, and now you're cutting it shorter." That's not you being an idiot—that's what happens when you're already questioning yourself and someone in authority doubles down on the blame. It's hard to advocate for yourself when you're halfway convinced they're right.

Here's what I'm hearing: the requirements kept changing (not your fault), you could've flagged issues earlier (on you), and now the deadline's impossible (definitely not on you). So yeah, it's both—but "both" doesn't mean equal. One of those things is about communication timing. The other is about being set up to fail.

The fact that you didn't push back in the meeting makes sense given everything else. But I'm wondering: if you could rewind to that moment, what would "pushing back" even look like? Because sometimes we beat ourselves up for not doing something we've never actually practiced or seen modeled.

**Your mom and the wedding:**

The texting-but-not-calling pattern is interesting. It keeps the pressure on without giving you a chance to actually talk it through. And you're right that this decision has no good outcome the way it's framed: say no and she won't let it go, say yes and resent everyone.

That weight in your chest when you think about it—what's it connected to? Is it dread about the event itself (the speech, being around family, the performance of it all), or is it more about the fallout from your mom if you don't go? Because those are different problems.

One thing that might help: what if the question wasn't "wedding yes or no" but "what version of this could I actually tolerate?" Like, could you go but skip the speech? Go for one day instead of the whole weekend? Set a boundary somewhere in the middle? Or does even thinking about compromise feel like giving in?

**Still tired:**

Yeah. You're carrying a lot right now, and neither situation has an easy exit. That kind of tired isn't just physical.

exchanges.user:
so i did push back. sort of. told my manager this morning that the requirements kept shifting and i needed clarity on what was actually due. he said "yeah that's fair" and then... nothing changed. still the same deadline. so at least i tried, i guess. doesn't really matter though.

been thinking about what you said about the wedding. the thing is, i don't actually want to go. that's the real answer. not that i'm torn, not that i need a compromise. i just don't want to be there. but saying that to my mom feels impossible. she'll ask why a million times and make it about her and i'll end up caving anyway so what's the point of saying no now.

the weight in my chest is just... knowing she's going to be disappointed no matter what. at least if i go i can pretend it's for family. if i don't go, i'm just the guy who let everyone down.

work's slightly less insane but also somehow worse? like my manager acknowledged the timeline issue but didn't actually fix it, so now i'm in this limbo where i can't tell if he thinks it's my problem to solve or his. feels like i'm waiting for the next thing to blow up. maybe i should just start looking for a job.
exchanges.assistant:
**Pushing back at work:**

You did push back—you named the shifting requirements and asked for clarity. Your manager said "yeah that's fair" and then did nothing. That's not "sort of" pushing back, that's you doing exactly what you were supposed to do and him failing to follow through. The outcome sucked, but the action itself? You did it.

The "doesn't really matter though" part—I get why it feels that way. You spoke up and the situation didn't change, so it's tempting to think the speaking up was pointless. But here's what did change: you now have confirmation that this isn't a communication problem on your end. He acknowledged the issue and chose not to fix it. That's different information than "maybe if I'd just explained it better." This is a management problem, not a you problem.

The job search thought makes sense. When you're in limbo waiting for the next thing to blow up, and your manager won't clarify whose problem this is, that's a reasonable signal that the environment itself might be the issue.

**The wedding—the real answer:**

"I don't actually want to go. That's the real answer." That's the clearest thing you've said about this, and it matters that you can say it out loud, even if it's just to me right now.

The prediction you're making is: if you say no, she'll ask why a million times, make it about her, and you'll cave anyway. That's probably based on a lot of history. But let me ask this: what if you didn't engage with the "why a million times" part? Like, what if your answer to "why?" was just "I'm not able to make it work" on repeat, without defending or explaining?

I know that sounds impossible. And maybe it is—maybe she escalates until you give in, and you've seen that movie before. But the weight in your chest is about her disappointment either way. If she's going to be disappointed whether you go or don't go, then the question becomes: which version of disappointed can you live with? The one where you honored what you actually want, or the one where you went and resented everyone?

You said "at least if I go I can pretend it's for family." But you'd know you didn't want to be there. Does that pretending actually protect you from feeling like you let them down, or does it just add resentment on top of the guilt?

**Work limbo:**

"Slightly less insane but somehow worse" is a perfect description of acknowledged-but-unfixed problems. You're stuck in this zone where he admitted the issue exists but won't say if it's yours to solve, so you're just… waiting. That's exhausting in a different way than the crisis was.

If you do start looking, you'll at least have some control back. Even if you don't leave right away, knowing you have options can take the edge off the waiting-for-explosion feeling.

exchanges.user:
quick update on the work thing. i actually started looking at job postings last night. nothing great out there tbh. but the act of looking made me feel a little less trapped, which is weird. like at least i have an exit if i need one.

anyway. told my mom no. just said i'm not coming to the wedding. didn't explain why, just kept saying "it's not going to work" when she asked. she did ask why a million times like you said. but i didn't cave. that's something i guess.

now she's not texting. hasn't heard from her in like two days. which should feel like relief but instead it just feels like waiting for the other shoe to drop. like she's mad and plotting something or just gave up on me entirely. both feel bad.

the weight's still there but different now. less about making a decision and more about... i don't know. knowing i disappointed her and can't take it back. even though i didn't want to go anyway.
exchanges.assistant:
**Job search as agency:**

The fact that looking at postings made you feel less trapped—even though nothing out there is great—tells you something important. It's not about finding the perfect job right now. It's about reminding yourself you have options. That shift from "I'm stuck here and have to make this work" to "I could leave if I need to" changes the whole emotional weight of showing up every day. You gave yourself an exit, and that matters even if you never use it.

**You told your mom no:**

You did it. You said no, she asked why a million times, and you didn't cave. You just kept saying "it's not going to work" without defending or justifying. That's exactly what I was talking about—and you actually pulled it off. That's not "something I guess," that's huge. You held a boundary with someone who has a long history of getting you to fold.

**The silence and the waiting:**

Now she's not texting, and you're stuck in this weird limbo where the silence feels worse than the pressure did. That makes complete sense. When someone's been pushing and suddenly goes quiet, your brain fills in the gap with worst-case scenarios: she's furious, she's done with you, she's planning some escalation. The not-knowing is its own kind of torture.

Here's the thing though: her silence is also a choice. She could text and say "I'm disappointed but I understand," or "I'm hurt and need some space," or literally anything that gives you information. Instead she's leaving you to wonder. I don't think that's an accident—it keeps the pressure on you without her having to say anything.

The weight shifted from "making a decision" to "knowing I disappointed her and can't take it back." But you didn't want to go. You knew that clearly. So the disappointment was always going to happen—either hers if you didn't go, or yours if you went and resented everyone. You chose yours over hers, and now you're sitting with what that feels like.

Does any part of you feel relieved that you're not going? Or is it all just guilt and waiting right now?

exchanges.user:
so my manager asked me to stay late today to "talk about the project." i was dreading it all day but turns out he just wanted to go over the new timeline with me and actually gave me some breathing room. pushed some stuff to next sprint, deprioritized a few things. said he knows the requirements were a mess and he should've locked them down earlier. basically admitted it wasn't all on me.

which is good. but now i feel weird about it because i was already halfway mentally checking out, looking at those job postings. like i had made peace with maybe leaving and now he's being reasonable and i don't know what to do with that. the relief doesn't feel clean, you know?

also my mom texted. just one text, no follow up. said "i'm sorry for pushing so hard about the wedding. you're an adult and you get to decide." that's it. which sounds nice but also feels like she's just... giving up on having any real relationship with me? like the apology is almost worse because at least before she was trying. now it feels like she's accepted that i'm just a disappointment and we'll never be close.

i hate that i can't just feel good about either of these things.
exchanges.assistant:
**Your manager coming through:**

He actually did it—pushed things to next sprint, deprioritized tasks, admitted the requirements were a mess and that he should've locked them down sooner. That's real movement, not just "yeah that's fair" with no follow-through. He took responsibility.

But now you're sitting with this weird feeling because you'd already started the mental exit process. You were making peace with leaving, looking at postings, imagining a way out—and now he's being reasonable, which scrambles that whole narrative. It makes sense that the relief doesn't feel clean. You'd built up momentum toward "this place is broken, I need to go," and now you're getting evidence that maybe it's not totally broken. That whiplash is disorienting.

The question isn't whether you should feel grateful or whether this fixes everything. The question is: does this change enough for you to want to stay? Because he can be reasonable about one timeline and still create the same pattern again in three months. Or this could be a turning point where he actually manages differently going forward. You don't have to decide right now. You can keep the job search warm in the background and see if this sticks.

**Your mom's text:**

"I'm sorry for pushing so hard. You're an adult and you get to decide." That does sound nice on the surface. But I hear what you're picking up on—it also feels like withdrawal. Like she's not saying "I respect your choice and I still want to connect with you," she's saying "fine, I'll stop trying."

Here's the painful part: you're interpreting her stepping back as her giving up on the relationship. But the thing she's stepping back from wasn't actually connection—it was pressure. She was pushing you to do something you didn't want to do, you held a boundary, and now she's stopped pushing. That's what you needed her to do. But it doesn't feel like a win because the question underneath is: can she still show up and care about you without the agenda? Or was the pushing the only way she knows how to stay connected?

You don't know yet. This is one text. It might be her genuinely trying to respect your boundary. It might be her punishing you with distance. It might be her feeling hurt and not knowing what to say next. You won't know until you see what comes after the silence.

**"I hate that I can't just feel good about either of these things":**

Of course you can't just feel good. Your manager being reasonable doesn't erase the weeks of chaos and blame. Your mom apologizing doesn't erase the years of dynamics that made saying no feel impossible in the first place. Relief mixed with suspicion, gratitude mixed with resentment—that's what it feels like when a hard thing shifts but the history is still sitting there.

You're allowed to feel complicated about good news. It doesn't mean you're broken or ungrateful. It means you're paying attention.

exchanges.user:
been a few days. work is... actually manageable right now? like i'm still skeptical that it'll last but the breathing room helps. manager's been leaving me alone mostly, which is weird after the constant pressure. part of me keeps waiting for it to flip back.

but that's not really why i'm writing.

my mom called yesterday. not texted. called. and i almost didn't answer because i was expecting her to either apologize again or start pushing about something else. but she just wanted to know how i was doing. like actually doing. not asking me to do anything, just asking.

we talked for like 20 minutes and it was fine. normal. she asked about work, i gave her an update, she listened. then she said she was sorry again but this time it felt different. like she meant it differently. not sorry for pushing about the wedding, sorry that she's been pushing me in general and hadn't really noticed.

i don't know what to do with that. it's good, right? but i also feel weirdly angry. like where was this years ago? why did it take me saying no to the wedding for her to even notice? and now i'm mad at myself for being angry when she's actually trying.

anyway the weight's lighter but the anger's weirder. idk.
exchanges.assistant:
**Work being manageable:**

The skepticism makes sense—you've been through enough whiplash to know that "fine right now" doesn't guarantee "fine next week." But the breathing room is real, even if it's temporary. The fact that your manager's leaving you alone after the constant pressure might feel weird, but it's also what you needed. You don't have to trust that it'll last forever to let yourself benefit from it right now.

**Your mom's call:**

She called just to ask how you're doing. No agenda, no push, just asking. And then she apologized differently—not just for the wedding, but for the pattern of pushing in general and not noticing. That's a real shift. She's naming something bigger than one event.

And now you're sitting with this weird anger that showed up right when she started trying. That's not you being ungrateful or broken—that's what happens when someone finally shows up the way you needed and your brain goes, "Wait, so you could've done this the whole time?"

The anger makes perfect sense. You spent years adapting to her pressure, learning to manage her reactions, swallowing what you actually wanted because it was easier than the fight. You said no to one wedding and suddenly she's capable of listening, respecting boundaries, asking how you are without an agenda attached. It raises the question: if she can do this now, why didn't she do it before? What changed? And the painful answer is: you had to fight for it. You had to say no hard enough that she finally heard it.

That's infuriating. Because it means all those years of accommodating her—that wasn't inevitable. She was capable of this all along, and you didn't get it until you drew a line.

**Being mad at yourself for being angry:**

You're layering guilt on top of the anger: "She's actually trying, why am I still mad?" But anger isn't about whether someone's trying now—it's about what happened before. You can be glad she's changing AND angry that it took this long. Both are true. Both are fair.

The anger isn't going to disappear just because she apologized. It might soften over time if she keeps showing up this way. But right now, it's information. It's telling you that the years of pressure mattered, that the cost of keeping the peace was real, and that you're allowed to feel the weight of that even as things start to shift.

**The weight's lighter but the anger's weirder:**

Yeah. Because relief and anger can sit right next to each other. The weight lifting doesn't mean the anger goes away—it just means you finally have room to feel it without the immediate crisis on top of it.

What does the anger want? Not what should it want, but what does it actually feel like it's asking for?

exchanges.user:
been thinking about what you said. about the anger wanting something. and i realized i don't actually know what i want from her. like is it an apology for specific things? is it her acknowledging how much it cost me to keep her happy all those years? is it just... time? idk.

had lunch with her today which was weird. she was trying, like genuinely trying to be different, but i kept waiting for her to slip back into old patterns. she didn't really. but i also couldn't just relax into it because i was too busy watching for it.

on the work front, manager's still being reasonable which is good but also i'm noticing i don't really care that much anymore? like the relief is there but i'm not invested in making it work now. which is stupid because he's actually changed but i already mentally left. feels like i wasted the energy on the job search when i could've given this more time. or maybe i just checked out too hard to come back.

anyway. sorry for dumping all this. mom situation is less urgent now so that's something.
exchanges.assistant:
**Anger and not knowing what you want:**

That's actually a really honest place to land—"I don't know what I want from her." Sometimes anger is clear: it wants an apology, or acknowledgment, or changed behavior. But sometimes it's murkier than that, and you're just sitting with this feeling that something was wrong and you're still processing what it cost you.

The things you listed—apology for specific things, her acknowledging the cost, time—those all feel like they're circling something. Maybe the anger isn't asking for one specific thing. Maybe it's asking for proof that this shift is real and lasting, not just a temporary reaction to you finally pushing back hard enough.

**Lunch with your mom:**

She was genuinely trying to be different, and you spent the whole time watching for her to slip back. Of course you did. You've seen her try before, or say the right thing in the moment, and then revert when the pressure's off. So your brain's in pattern-recognition mode: "Is this real or is this temporary?"

The hard part is that you won't know if it's real until time passes. You can't relax into it yet because you don't have enough data. That's not you being unfair to her—that's you being realistic based on history. Trust gets rebuilt slowly, not in one lunch.

One thing you could try: instead of waiting to see if she slips, maybe notice if there are small moments where she does something differently and it actually lands for you. Not forcing yourself to trust her, just tracking the moments where her effort feels genuine. Over time, that might give you more information than watching for the slip.

**Work and checking out:**

Your manager's being reasonable, the situation improved, but you don't care anymore. You already left mentally, and now it feels like you wasted energy on the job search when you "should've" given this more time.

Here's the thing: you didn't waste anything. You checked out because the situation was broken and he wasn't fixing it. The job search gave you agency when you had none. The fact that he changed afterward doesn't mean you were wrong to start looking—it means you were responding to the reality at the time.

And now the reality is different, but you're still checked out. That's not stupid. That's what happens when you go through the mental process of leaving—you grieve the job, you imagine life elsewhere, you stop investing emotionally as a protective move. You can't just flip that switch back because the circumstances improved.

The real question isn't "should I have waited longer?" It's "do I actually want to re-invest here, or did checking out show me something true about how I feel about this job regardless of whether my manager's reasonable?"

Maybe the chaos was the problem and now it's fixed, so you could come back if you wanted. Or maybe the chaos revealed that you were already halfway out the door for other reasons, and his behavior just accelerated the exit. You won't know until you sit with it for a bit. But either way, checking out wasn't a mistake—it was information.

**"Sorry for dumping all this":**

You don't need to apologize. This is what this space is for.

exchanges.user:
been a week or so and things have gotten weird in a different way. like, work's fine, manager's still being reasonable, but i realized i actually do want to stay? not because i think it'll be perfect or because he's suddenly amazing. just because the alternative—starting over somewhere new—feels like more energy than i have right now. so i guess i'm not leaving. that job search was useful even if it just confirmed i'd rather deal with what i know.

the mom thing is actually... different now. we've talked a few more times and she's not slipping back into the pushing. like she'll still have opinions about stuff but she asks first instead of just telling me what i should do. yesterday she asked about something i was stressed about and didn't try to fix it, just listened. which sounds small but it's not small to me.

here's the weird part though. now that she's actually respecting my boundaries, i feel guilty. like i'm mad that she didn't do it sooner but also grateful that she's doing it now, and those two things are clashing and i don't know which one to feel. some days i want to tell her "thank you for finally getting it" and other days i want to ask "why did it take so long?" and i haven't actually said either thing out loud.

also i'm tired again but in a different way than before. not the exhausted-from-chaos tired. more like... emptied out? like now that the emergency's over on both fronts, i'm realizing how much energy i was burning just staying in crisis mode. don't know what to do with myself when i'm not fighting something.
exchanges.assistant:
**Work and choosing to stay:**

You landed somewhere real: you're staying not because the job became perfect, but because starting over sounds like more than you can handle right now. That's not settling—that's making a choice based on actual capacity, not some ideal version of what you "should" want. The job search did its job even though you're not leaving. It gave you information about what else is out there and confirmed that dealing with the known quantity feels more manageable than the unknown right now. That's useful data.

**Your mom respecting boundaries:**

She's asking instead of telling. She listened to your stress without trying to fix it. That's not small—you're right about that. Those are real shifts in how she shows up, and they're the kind of shifts that only stick if she keeps doing them over time. The fact that she hasn't slipped back yet is something.

**Guilt and gratitude clashing:**

Of course they're clashing. You're mad it took this long AND grateful she's finally doing it. Both feelings are true at the same time, and neither one cancels the other out. The anger says "this cost me years and you could've done this sooner." The gratitude says "I'm glad you're trying now and I can feel the difference." You don't have to pick one.

The two things you haven't said out loud—"thank you for finally getting it" and "why did it take so long?"—those could both be worth saying eventually. Not in the same conversation necessarily, and not right now if it doesn't feel right. But at some point, telling her both might help. She should know that her effort matters to you, and she should also know that the years before this mattered too. You don't owe her protection from that reality.

For now, it's okay to just sit with the clash. You don't have to resolve it or figure out which feeling is the "right" one. They're both real.

**Emptied out tired:**

You were running on crisis fuel for a long time—manager chaos, mom pressure, wedding decision, job search, all of it—and your system was flooded with adrenaline and vigilance just to keep up. Now that the emergencies have settled, your body's finally letting you feel the exhaustion that was there all along.

That "emptied out" feeling is what happens when the fight-or-flight system finally gets to stand down. You were burning so much energy just staying upright in the chaos that now, without the chaos, you don't know what to do with the space. It's like you built all these muscles for fighting and now you're standing in a quiet room with no idea how to just... be.

This phase is uncomfortable but it's also necessary. Your system needs time to recalibrate. You don't have to "do" anything with yourself right now. The emptied-out feeling will shift as your body catches up to the fact that the crisis is actually over. In the meantime, if you can, let yourself rest without needing it to be productive rest. That might mean doing less, saying no to things, or just sitting with the quiet even though it feels weird.

What does a normal week look like for you now that you're not fighting something? Are you filling the space with anything, or is it just... empty?

exchanges.user:
yeah so i've been trying to just... sit with the quiet like you said. which sounds simple but it's kind of messing with me. like i'll be home after work and there's nothing urgent and i realize i don't actually know what i want to do with myself. not in a "i'm bored" way. more like i forgot how to want things that aren't about solving a problem or managing someone else's reaction.

spent like three hours scrolling yesterday just to avoid the feeling. which is fine i guess, but it made me realize how much of my brain space was taken up by work drama and my mom stuff. now that it's gone i'm just... empty. and not even the good kind of empty where you get to reset. just kind of lost.

also work's fine. nothing new there. it's fine.

mom asked if i wanted to get dinner next week and i said yes without overthinking it for once. which felt good in the moment but now i'm second-guessing if i only said yes because i'm supposed to be grateful or whatever. like am i actually wanting to see her or am i just falling back into the pattern of accommodating her? that's the thing that's bugging me.
exchanges.assistant:
**Sitting with the quiet:**

You're three hours into scrolling and you realize—you don't actually know what you want to do when there's no problem to solve or reaction to manage. That's not a small realization. You've spent so long in reactive mode (fix the work thing, manage your mom, prepare for the next crisis) that the muscles for "what do I actually want right now?" have atrophied.

The empty feeling isn't the good reset kind because you're not empty in a cleared-out way—you're empty in a "who am I when I'm not firefighting?" way. That's disorienting. You haven't had space to figure out what you want outside of crisis mode, so now that you have the space, there's just... nothing there yet. That void is real, and scrolling for three hours is your brain's way of avoiding sitting in it. Which makes sense—the void is uncomfortable.

Here's something you could try: next time you're home and there's nothing urgent, instead of asking "what do I want to do?" try asking "what would feel okay right now?" Not good, not exciting, just okay. Sometimes when we've lost touch with wanting, we have to start smaller—just noticing what feels tolerable versus what feels like static. Maybe that's putting on music, or going for a walk, or cooking something simple, or doing nothing and letting yourself actually be bored instead of scrolling to avoid it. You're rebuilding the ability to notice your own preferences from scratch. That takes time.

**Work's fine:**

Yeah, I hear that. "It's fine" after everything that happened is both a relief and kind of anticlimactic. The chaos is gone but so is the charge that came with it. Fine is stable, and stable can feel flat when you're used to running hot.

**Dinner with your mom:**

You said yes without overthinking it, which felt good in the moment. Now you're second-guessing whether you actually want to see her or if you're just falling back into the pattern of accommodating her out of guilt or obligation.

Here's one way to check: when you imagine the dinner itself—sitting across from her, talking—what's the feeling? Is it dread, neutral, or something that feels like actual want (even a small want)? You don't have to feel excited about it for it to be real. "I think this will be fine and I'm curious how it goes" is different from "I don't want to do this but I feel like I should."

It's possible you said yes because you're supposed to be grateful. It's also possible you said yes because she's been showing up differently and some part of you wants to see if that continues. Or maybe you said yes because it was easier than saying no and you don't have the energy to fight right now. All of those are real reasons, and not all of them are bad reasons.

The fact that you're questioning it means you're paying attention to your own motives, which is good. But you won't really know if this was accommodating or wanting until you're actually at the dinner. If you get there and you're glad you went—even if it's not perfect—that's data. If you get there and you resent being there the whole time, that's different data. You don't have to know in advance.

One thing you could track: do you feel like you can leave the dinner if you want to? Like if it goes badly or you just hit your limit, do you have permission (from yourself) to say "I need to head out"? Because if the answer is "I have to stay no matter what," that might tell you something about whether this is accommodation or choice.

exchanges.user:
